citeinfo.title: Counting Chandalar Salmon - Alaska Sea Grant Radio Show

descript.abstract: Subsistence fishing for fall chum salmon opened this week on the Chandalar River, a tributary of the Yukon River north of Fairbanks. Fisheries managers opened the season after 74,000 fall chums passed a sonar counting station operated by the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service. The opening is sure to help the Native villages of Venetie and Fort Yukon, two rural communities that depend on subsistence harvests of fish and game. Recently, Arctic Science Journeys Radio reporter Doug Schneider visited the Chandalar River sonar station to learn more about how biologists count migrating salmon.
descript.purpose: The Chandalar River is the color of green tea as it makes its way out of Alaskaﾒs Brooks Range north of Fairbanks, past the Gwichﾒin Native village of Venetie, and into the broad 11 million acre floodplain of the Yukon Flats National Wildlife Refuge.
